nameEntry.part: The Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton

biogHist.abstract: The Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton, was the new name given to the Girls' Probationary School in 1945 when the government ceased control of the School. It initially only accommodated girls placed privately. At different times Aboriginal girls were also accommodated at the Home. In 1950 the Home once again came under government supervision. In 1969 the Salvation Army Girls' Home began to also admit younger boys and was renamed the Fullarton Children's Home.
biogHist.p: The Salvation Army Girls' Home at 39 Florence Street, Fullarton, was previously known as the Girls' Probationary School. Its name was changed by the Salvation Army in 1945 when the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board ceased control of the School and removed it from the gazetted list of government approved private institutions. It continued to also be known as The Haven.
For a number of years the Salvation Army Girls' Home only accommodated girls placed privately. Aboriginal girls were also accommodated at the Home at different times throughout its existence.

In 1950 the Home once again came under government supervision when amendments were made to the Maintenance Act 1926-37 requiring all institutions that accommodated children under the age of seven to be regularly inspected. In 1965, the new Social Welfare Act came into effect which required the matron of the Home to apply to the government for a licence to run a children's home.
In 1969 the Salvation Army Girls' Home began to admit younger boys and was renamed the Fullarton Children's Home.

chronItem.event: Address - The Salvation Army Girls Home was situated at 39 Florence Street, Fullarton

descriptiveNote.p: The Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton was run by the Salvation Army under the control of the State Children's Council, the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board and its successors.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Children in State Care Commission of Inquiry, State of South Australia (2004 - 2008)
Records of the Social Welfare Department and predecessors (1849 - c. 1987)
Records of The Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton, The Salvation Army Australia Southern Territory Territorial Archives and Museum (1900? - 1980s)

descriptiveNote.p: The Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton, was regularly inspected by the Department of Social Welfare

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Index to the War Cry [Periodical], Salvation Army Magazine (1883 - )

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Salvation Army Territorial Archives and Museum. This electronic index can be searched for information and articles relating to this Home appearing in the Salvation Army Magazine 'War Cry'.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: State Ward Index Cards, State Children's Department and successors (1900 - 1992)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by State Records of SA. State Ward Index Cards were small cards created when a child came under the control of the Department. They contain various amounts of information. Some may relate to children who were resident at the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Minutes - State Children's Council, later the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board (1886 - 1965)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by State Records of SA. These large volumes of minutes include entries related to the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Correspondence files ('CW & PRD' and 'SW' files) -Children's Welfare and Public Relief Department and successors (1927 - c. 1979)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by State Records of SA. These correspondence files cover all aspects of the business of the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Department. It includes some correspondence related to Homes run by the Salvation Army including the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board (1927 - 1966)

descriptiveNote.p: The Salvation Army Girls' Home, Fullarton, was regularly inspected by the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board, and its successors, from 1950
